article.headline: Are you overlooking this critical factor in deciding what is the âbest placeâ to retire?
article.body: This article is reprinted by permission from NextAvenue.org. When Bill and Annemarie Kachur retired in early 2016, they saw no reason to go anywhere. The gray shingled bungalow in Myrtle Beach, S.C. had been their home for more than 15 years. âIâve been here so long, itâs a sense of roots now for me,â says Bill, 65, who spent his early career hopping around the country, working on-air at various radio stations. Plus, they were already in a haven for retirees. âI like the fact that there isnât a winter,â says Annemarie, whoâll be 65 in September. But in recent years, their idyllic spot about 2Â½ miles from the Atlantic Ocean has revealed an ominous side: hurricane season. âI just noticed that the last four or five years, we keep getting hammered,â recalls Bill. Two hurricane evacuations since 2016 Since 2016, the Kachurs have ridden out four hurricanes, including two evacuations to safer ground. âTen months out of the year, itâs great,â says Bill. âAnd then thereâs a couple months out of the year when youâre walking on eggshells and youâre a little bit concerned about whatâs blowinâ in the wind, so to speak.â Warm, beachy spots on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf Coasts have been retirement magnets for decades. But, as Hurricane Laura just underscored, theyâre also squarely in the crosshairs of the changing climate, effects of which are already evident in many of the nationâs most popular retirement destinations.Climate change and retirement location decisions âCurrent climate andÂ future climateÂ is absolutely something that people should be thinking about when deciding where to live, where to retire,â advises Radley Horton, a climate scientist at Columbia Universityâs Earth Institute, who has focused on climate adaptation strategies. âThose are absolutely critical concerns when you think about impacts directly on the home, but also livability outdoors â things like critical infrastructure, too,â says Horton. Rising seas are threatening things we tend to take for granted in many areas, like major freeways, airports and sewage treatment plants. The hazards of wildfires and extreme heat are also intensifying due to climate change. Coastal communities are particularly at risk. As the atmosphere warms, it retains more water vapor, which often translates into tropical storms that dump previously unseen amounts of precipitation â more than 50 inches within 48 hours for Hurricane Harvey, when it stalled over the Houston area in August 2017. Harvey remains one of the costliest weather disasters on record, causing $125 billion in damage.A frightening future Climate change experts believe the future looks even more harrowing. Whether itâs ferocious winds, storm surge or rain-driven flooding, Eric Jay Dolan writes inÂ âA Furious Sky,â his 500-year history of hurricanes, âbecause of global warming, hurricanes of the future will most likely be worse than those of the past.â And extreme weather events are expected to become more common as global heating intensifies. A recent survey by Stanford University, the Resources for the Future research group and the ReconMR research firm, however, found that 68% of Americans want the U.S. government to do more to deal with global warming. Some popular lists of top retirement spots include environmental factors such as air quality, but itâs rare to see any consideration given to present and future impacts from climate change.What the best places lists say (and donât say) Take the U.S. News list ofÂ 25 Best Places to Retire in 2020. It includes nine cities in Florida, citing âaffordable homes, low taxes and high ratings for happiness and desirability.â No. 14, Miami, is not only in Hurricane Alley, but already sees âsunny-dayâ flooding at high tides on a regular basis, the result of rising sea levels. For the first time, Forbes magazine hasÂ included climate risk in its latest Top 25 listÂ of most desirable retirement towns. But the list is still heavily clustered along the southeast coast of the country. Cities on it, from Virginia Beach, Va. to Savannah, Ga. to Sarasota, Fla., are all strung out along Hurricane Alley. The Forbes list also includes Mesa and Green Valley in Arizona, a state which has experienced record heat of late. Interestingly, no place in California makes the grade. Prohibitive real-estate prices are no doubt a factor, but relentless droughts and a string of increasingly catastrophic wildfire seasons have given many people pause about making the Golden State their home in retirement.In Arizona, heat and water worries Six years ago, Gail Fox Johnson and her husband, John, sold their home in Marin County, Calif. and moved into a planned, 55+ community outside Scottsville, Ariz. Though Gail describes their new surroundings outside as âstaggeringly beautiful,â they might not stay. âThe heat is so bad that you cannot go out of your house,â she says. âYou canât take the dog for a walk without booties.â A recent record-setting stretch of heat got the couple thinking about returning to the West Coast, where Johnâs sons still live. âForty-two days of over 110, and 25 consecutive days of over 115,â she recited. âHell, we canât even go out.â The Phoenix area has had 50 days of 110 F or higher this summer. Also see:Iâve got a budget of $3,300 a month and want to be near some âwildâ areas â where should I retire? Fox Johnson also worries about future water supplies in her central Arizona area, as development of another 2,000 homes looms nearby, with plans to tap into her communityâs water supply. Scientists say that drought is an increasing threat to southwestern states, with the future of water supplies from the Colorado River in doubt.Americaâs most climate-proof city? No place will be immune from the impacts of a warming planet. In 2019, the New York Times touted Duluth, Minn. as Americaâs most climate-proof city, arguing that because of geographic factors, the region âwill be one of the few places in America where the effects of climate change may be more easily managed.â Read: âI hate the humidity and can do with a lot less snow and ice, and my husband hates the extreme heatâ â where should we retire? But even Duluth is facing climate change challenges. Itâs contending with fluctuating water levels in Lake Superior, which threaten shoreline development. More southern Midwestern cities face the threat of extreme heat waves.The warming problem in the Midwest University of Notre DameâsÂ Global Adaptation Initiative researchers have assessed climate riskÂ in 278 U.S. cities, through their Urban Adaptation Assessment tool. They concluded that âeight of the top 10 cities facing the highest likelihood of extreme heat in 2040 are located in the Midwest.â That list includes a cluster of cities in Michigan, from Detroit in the east to Grand Rapids in the West. Cincinnati, Indianapolis and Dayton, Ohio also face high probability of future heat events, according to Notre Dame researchers. The city with the highest probability of an extreme heat event in 2040, according to Notre Dame: Clarksville, Tenn. The Notre Dame assessment also lets you plug in the name of any big city to determine its climate change risk and readiness.Which locales seem less risky? No place is wholly immune, of course. But areas like New England and the Pacific Northwest have steep coastlines which provide a buffer against high-tide flooding and storm surge. Horton says higher elevations inland should also provide some climate change protection, not just from flooding but also from rising temperatures and humidity. âIn general,â he says, âanywhere you have elevation, even itâs just 1,000 feet, 1,500 feet, protects you from humid heat, which is particularly dangerous.â Paradoxically, adds Horton, âThereâs been migration away from some of the places that are looking relatively good in the future â places like the Great Lakes.â Meanwhile, the Kachurs are pondering whether theyâve found retirement serenity in Myrtle Beach or if a move to higher ground â maybe the Piedmont region of North Carolina â would be prudent. There, Bill might finally be freed of something thatâs become a nearly annual ritual: putting metal hurricane shutters over the windows. âThe 65-year-old is thinking about the 75-year-old in me and do I want to be doing that in 10 years?â he muses. âAnd the answer is no.â Craig Millerâs career in broadcasting and journalism spans more than 40 years, though since 2008, his focus has been on tracking climate science and policy. Miller launched and edited the award-winning Climate Watch multimedia initiative for KQED in San Francisco, where he remained a science editor until August of 2019. Prior to KQED, he spent two decades as a television reporter and documentary producer at major-market stations, as well as CNN and MSNBC.
